item.label: Cerebral lobes, Temporal
item.name: Cerebral lobes, temporal
item.description: The temporal lobe is the most inferior lobe of the cerebral hemispheres.  It is located below the lateral sulcus and anterior to the occipital lobe. Important structures within the temporal lobe include: auditory sensory and association cortex, part of the posterior language cortex, visual and higher-order association cortex, primary and association olfactory cortex, amygdala, hippocampus and the inferior or temporal horn of the lateral ventricle.

item.label: Cerebral gyri, Insula
item.name: Cerebral gyri Insula
item.description: The insula is an area of cerebral cortex (AKA insular cortex or Island of Reil) that is concealed by the opercula of the frontal, parietal and temporal gyri. It was originally the lateral surface of the telencephalon but was overgrown during development by the other cerebral lobes. It generally consists of three short gyri located anteriorly and two long gyri located posteriorly.

item.label: Cerebral sulci & fissures
item.name: Cerebral sulci_fissures
item.description: A cerebral fissure is AKA a cerebral sulcus (sing.); sulci (pl.).  Fissures are the depressions or grooves between the gyri or convolutions of the cerebral cortex.  Fissure generally refers to a sulcus that is particularly deep.  The terms are used interchangeably in some cases.

item.label: Longitudinal fissure
item.name: Longitudinal fissure
item.description: The longitudinal cerebral fissure is AKA the median longitudinal fissure. it is a deep midline fissure located between the two cerebral hemispheres.  The cerebral falx (a dural reflection) extends into this fissure.

item.label: Lateral sulci
item.name: Lateral sulci
item.description: The lateral fissure or sulcus is AKA the Sylvian fissure. It is a long, deep sulcus on the lateral aspect of each cerebral hemisphere that separates the frontal and parietal lobes from the temporal lobe.  The main portion of the fissure is sometimes referred to as the posterior ramus.  Anteriorly, the fissure branches to subdivide the inferior frontal gyrus; anterior horizontal and anterior ascending rami delineate the orbital, triangular and opercular portions of the inferior frontal gyrus.  The cortex known as the insula is located deep within this sulcus and the transverse temporal gyri (auditory cortex) is located on the temporal lobe aspect of the fissure.

item.label: Commissure, Corpus callosum, genu
item.name: Commissure Corpus callosum,
item.description: The corpus callosum is a massive curved commissure that interconnects corresponding areas of the two cerebral hemispheres so that these areas may function in a coordinated manner.

item.label: Internal capsule, Anterior limb
item.name: Internal capsule Anterior l
item.description: The anterior limb of the internal capsule is located between the lenticular nucleus laterally and the head of the caudate nucleus medially. It includes thalamocortical fibers from the dorsomedial and anterior thalamic nuclei to the prefrontal and cingulate areas of cerebral cortex as well as corticopontine fibers.

item.label: Corpus striatum
item.name: Corpus striatum
item.description: The corpus striatum includes the caudate nuclei, putamen and globus pallidus.  These nuclei are often referred to as the basal ganglia.   Note that the term "striatum" includes only the caudate nuclei plus the putamen.

item.label: Caudate nuclei, head
item.name: Caudate nuclei, head
item.description: The head of the caudate nucleus is the largest portion of the caudate.  It bulges into the anterior horn of the lateral ventricle. It is located medial to the anterior limb of the internal capsule.

item.label: Lentiform nuclei, Putamen
item.name: Lentiform nuclei Putamen
item.description: The putamen is the large lateral component of the lentiform nucleus, located lateral to the globus pallidus and the internal capsule. With the caudate nucleus, it is known as the striatum. Portion of the striatum most involved in the motor function of the basal ganglia. Receives afferents from motor and somatosensory cerebral cortex, substantia nigra and centromedian nucleus of the thalamus; sents efferents to globus pallidus.

item.label: Visual pathway, Optic nerves
item.name: Visual pathway Optic nerves
item.description: The Optic nerve or Cranial Nerve II consists of the axons of ganglion cells in the retina. The optic nerve axons will travel through the optic tract and then synapse in the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus as well as in the pretectum.  Between the optic nerve and lateral geniculate nucleus, the nerve fibers from the nasal half of the retina cross the midline in the optic chiasm and then enter the optic tract; the nerve fibers from the temporal half of the retina do not cross, but enter the optic tract directly.

item.label: Arteries, branches of
item.name: Arteries_branches of
item.description: The arterial supply to the brain is via the paired internal carotid and vertebral arteries. The terminal branches of the internal carotid arteries are the paired anterior and middle cerebral arteries which supply supratentorial structures.  The two vertebral arteries enter the cranial cavity via the foramen magnum; they join one another at the junction of the medulla with the pons to form the basilar artery.  Together the vertebral-basilar system of arteries supplies the structures of the posterior fossa as well as those supratentorial structures supplied by its terminal branches -- the posterior cerebral arteries.

item.label: Internal carotid
item.name: Internal carotid
item.description: With the verbebral arteries, the internal carotid arteries provide the blood supply to the brain. The internal carotid branches from the common carotid in the neck and enters the base of the skull via the carotid canal. As it enters the Circle of Willis, it divides into its two terminal branches: the middle and anterior cerebral arteries.

item.label: Anterior cerebral
item.name: Anterior cerebral
item.description: The anterior cerebral artery is the most anterior of the terminal branches of the internal carotid artery. Along with its branches, it curves around the genu and then superior to the corpus callosum to supply the orbital gyri, medial aspect of the frontal lobe, a portion of the parietal lobe and a narrow band along the most superior region of the lateral aspect of the hemisphere. Since the anterior cerebral artery supplies the paracentral lobule which is responsible for sensation and motor control of the contralateral lower extremity, loss of this blood supply results in paralysis and loss of sensation in the contralateral lower extremity.

item.label: Anterior communicating
item.name: Anterior communicating
item.description: The anterior communicating artery is a very short blood vessel that interconnects the two anterior cerebral arteries at the rostral or anterior aspect of the Circle of Willis.

item.label: Middle cerebral
item.name: Middle cerebral
item.description: The middle cerebral artery is the most posterior of the terminal branches of the internal carotid artery. Along with its branches, it travels through the lateral sulcus to supply the insula, the lateral aspect of the frontal and parietal lobes and the anterior tip of the temporal lobe. Since the middle cerebral artery supplies the pre- and post-central gyri which are responsible for sensation and motor control of the contralateral head, upper extremity and torso, loss of this blood supply results in paralysis and loss of sensation in the contralateral head, upper extremity and torso.

item.label: Cerebral veins, superficial
item.name: Cerebral veins, superficial
item.description: Cerebral veins are described as superficial or deep, depending on whether they drain the superficial or deep aspects of the brain.  In general, the superficial veins lie on the surface of the cerebral hemispheres, where most empty into the superior sagittal sinus.

item.label: Dural reflection, Falx cerebri
item.name: Dural reflection Falx cereb
item.description: The cerebral falx is AKA the falx cerebri.  Sickle-shaped dural reflection of the meningeal layer of the dura between the two cerebral hemispheres.

item.label: Dural venous sinuses
item.name: Dural venous sinuses
item.description: The dural venous sinuses are endothelial-lined spaces between the periosteal and meningeal layers of the dura.  They form where the meningeal layer of the dura is reflected away from the surface of the skull and into the spaces between parts of the brain such as the longitudinal fissure.  Included are the superior sagittal, inferior sagittal, straight, transverse, occipital, sigmoid, cavernous, superior petrosal, and inferior petrosal sinuses.  Most of the blood from the brain empties into these sinuses before draining into the internal jugular veins and leaving the cranium.

item.label: Superior sagittal
item.name: Superior sagittal
item.description: The superior sagittal sinus of the dural venous sinus system is located in the superior midline of the cerebral dura and thus, in the superior, attached edge of the cerebral falx. It receives venous blood from cerebral, diploic and emissary veins and joins the remainder of the sinus system at the confluence in the sinuses near the internal occipital protuberance.

item.label: Inferior sagittal
item.name: Inferior sagittal
item.description: The inferior sagittal sinus is a dural venous sinus located in the inferior aspect of the cerebral falx. It drains into the straight sinus.

item.label: Cavernous
item.name: Cavernous
item.description: The cavernous sinuses are located on either side of the sella turcica on the upper part of the sphenoid bone.  They consist of a venous plexus of thin-walled, interconnected veins.  There is communication between the two cavernous sinuses via the intercavernous sinuses.  Many functionally-important structures pass through the cavernous sinuses including the internal carotid artery, cranial nerves III, IV, V and VI.

item.label: Ventricular system, Lateral ventricle
item.name: Ventricular system Lateral
item.description: The lateral ventricle is a large, C-shaped space within each cerebral hemisphere that is filled with cerebrospinal fluid. It consists of an anterior (or frontal) horn that extends into the frontal lobe, a body, a posterior (or occipital) horn that extends into the occipital lobe, an inferior (or temporal) horn that extends into the temporal lobe and the atrium or trigone where the body, posterior limb and inferior limb meet.
